awd_titl_txt: New Tools for Absolute Molecular Structure Assignment
awd_abstract_narration:
The Rychnovsky lab is supported by the Chemical Synthesis Program in the Chemistry Division to develop a new strategy to assign the absolute configuration of molecules.  Molecules may exist in two possible mirror-image forms, which are commonly described as right-handed and left-handed molecules. The new strategy involves testing the molecule in question by reacting it with two mirror-image reagents specially chosen to differentiate right-handed and left-handed molecules.  Determining the more reactive reagent leads to identification of the handedness (configuration) of the molecule in question. Two mirror-image molecules interact with proteins, carbohydrates and other biological molecules differently, with one of the mirror-image molecules often having more favorable properties than the other.  Most modern pharmaceutical drugs are composed of only a single mirror image molecule as often only one of the two forms are beneficial to human health.  Assigning molecules to the correct mirror-image structure (configuration) is an important step in the developing new pharmaceutical agents, studying new natural product molecules, and in understanding their interactions with cells, animals, humans and other living creatures. Undergraduate and graduate students carry out the research for this project.  UC Irvine is a Hispanic Serving Institution, which provides ample opportunities to recruit talented Hispanic (and other minority) students to participate in this project.  Professor Rychnovsky works with the faculty at Santiago Community College providing their students with an avenue to develop their research skills and expertise.  This project benefits society by advancing human health as well as improving student training/employment in the pharmaceutical industries and medical sector.

The award supports development of the Competing Enantioselective Conversion (CEC) strategy for assigning the configuration of molecules. The new molecule is evaluated by measuring rates of reaction against two enantiomeric (mirror image) catalysts or reagents.  Kinetic resolution catalysts are ideal because they react with high enantioselectivity, showing significant rate differences between a matched case and a mismatched case. By measuring the rate or conversion of an enantiopure molecule against the two enantiomers of the reagent, the fast-reacting reagent can be identified.  Comparison with known examples allow the absolute configuration of the molecule to be assigned.  The program focuses on developing new reagents for differentiating alkenes and dienes with adjacent stereogenic centers.  The method for assigning secondary alcohol configuration is being adapted to identify a wider variety of structures.  The research is well suited for the training of new undergraduate scientists, and students with diverse backgrounds are recruited to participate in this project. Santiago Community College has many students who transfer to the UC system, but they rarely have the opportunity to participate in research projects.  Professor Rychnovsky works with the faculty there to recruit summer students to take part in this research program, thus providing an avenue for community college students to develop research skills and experience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project was to develop new tools for determining the absolute configuration of molecules, and to improve the synthesis of these molecules. Many molecules can exist in a right-handed or left-handed forms, and these two different forms have different properties.  (Molecules that have this property are called chiral.) Often pharmaceutical agents exist in these two forms, where the left-handed form may be active and the right-handed form may lead to side effects.  Identifying absolute configuration is essential to understanding the structure and properties of molecules and is a necessary step in pharmaceutical research.

The strategy we have developed is the Competing Enantioselective Conversion (CEC) method.  In this method, the enantiopure target molecule will be reacted with left-handed and right-handed forms of a chiral reagent.    The fast-reacting form will be identified and comparisons with benchmark compounds will allow the unknown configuration (handedness) of the target molecule to be assigned.  Learning which reaction is faster is accomplished by an analytical method to assess the amount of product formed in the two reactions.  In this award we focused on the configuration assignment of amines, which are nitrogen-containing molecules that have great importance in pharmaceutical agents. We had previously used analytical methods such as Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy. The focus here was using liquid chromatography with mass spectrometry detection (LCMS) a highly-sensitive technique.  Using mass-labelled reagents that selectively react with chiral amines, combined with LCMS analysis, lead to a selective and highly sensitive method to assign the configuration of amines.  The methods was demonstrated with cyclic amines and a number of active pharmaceutical agents, such as moxifloxacin methyl ester as shown in Figure 1 . The sensitivity of this improved CEC method is a significant improvement over traditional methods used to assign configuration.

 A complementary strategy was developed to improve the configurational assignment of molecules containing carbon-carbon double bonds?alkenes. X-Ray crystallography can be used to determine the 3D structure of molecules and under certain conditions also to assign the absolute configuration.  The first requirement is that the molecule form crystals.  Alkenes often do not crystallize?they are commonly liquids.  We discovered that alkenes react with an osmium oxidant in the presence of a diamine (TMEDA) will form a stable addition product, and that these products are very often crystalline.  Liquid alkenes could be coaxed for form crystalline derivatives, and these crystals often could be analyzed by X-ray crystallography to produce 3D molecular structures.  The presence of the heavy osmium element allowed absolute configuration to be assigned.  This new method provides a facile solution for the determination of absolute configurations and molecular structures for many alkenes. One example is shown in Figure 2. This method should useful in the fields of chemistry and medicinal chemistry.

The Competing Enantioselective Conversion method is relatively simple to perform, and it has been developed into a laboratory experiment for the introductory organic chemistry course at UC Irvine.  Over 7000 students have performed this lab, and the vast majority of them were able to identify the correct configuration of their test alcohol.  The details of this experiment have been published.  It provides an excellent starting point to explain the concept of chirality (handedness) and teach students how the handedness of molecules affects their properties.  In this way, the laboratory experiment gives students a direct demonstration of the effect of chirality and serves to popularize science.


Last Modified: 08/04/2022
Modified by: Scott Rychnovsky

Images (1 of )
  • Competitive amide formation with mass-labelled selective acylation reagents allows the configuration assignment of moxifloxacin methyl ester using a mass-sensitive LCMS analysis.
    Scott Rychnovsky
    Copyrighted
    Scott Rychnovsky
    Figure 1
  • Single enantiomer of a liquid alkene was derivatized with osmium tetroxide and TMEDA to produce a crystalline produce. Subsequent X-ray analysis provided the 3D structure and absolute configuration.
    Scott Rychnovsky
    Copyrighted
    Scott Rychnovsky
    Figure 2
por.por_txt_cntn:
The goal of the project was to develop new tools for determining the absolute configuration of molecules, and to improve the synthesis of these molecules. Many molecules can exist in a right-handed or left-handed forms, and these two different forms have different properties.  (Molecules that have this property are called chiral.) Often pharmaceutical agents exist in these two forms, where the left-handed form may be active and the right-handed form may lead to side effects.  Identifying absolute configuration is essential to understanding the structure and properties of molecules and is a necessary step in pharmaceutical research.

The strategy we have developed is the Competing Enantioselective Conversion (CEC) method.  In this method, the enantiopure target molecule will be reacted with left-handed and right-handed forms of a chiral reagent.    The fast-reacting form will be identified and comparisons with benchmark compounds will allow the unknown configuration (handedness) of the target molecule to be assigned.  Learning which reaction is faster is accomplished by an analytical method to assess the amount of product formed in the two reactions.  In this award we focused on the configuration assignment of amines, which are nitrogen-containing molecules that have great importance in pharmaceutical agents. We had previously used analytical methods such as Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy. The focus here was using liquid chromatography with mass spectrometry detection (LCMS) a highly-sensitive technique.  Using mass-labelled reagents that selectively react with chiral amines, combined with LCMS analysis, lead to a selective and highly sensitive method to assign the configuration of amines.  The methods was demonstrated with cyclic amines and a number of active pharmaceutical agents, such as moxifloxacin methyl ester as shown in Figure 1 . The sensitivity of this improved CEC method is a significant improvement over traditional methods used to assign configuration.

 A complementary strategy was developed to improve the configurational assignment of molecules containing carbon-carbon double bonds?alkenes. X-Ray crystallography can be used to determine the 3D structure of molecules and under certain conditions also to assign the absolute configuration.  The first requirement is that the molecule form crystals.  Alkenes often do not crystallize?they are commonly liquids.  We discovered that alkenes react with an osmium oxidant in the presence of a diamine (TMEDA) will form a stable addition product, and that these products are very often crystalline.  Liquid alkenes could be coaxed for form crystalline derivatives, and these crystals often could be analyzed by X-ray crystallography to produce 3D molecular structures.  The presence of the heavy osmium element allowed absolute configuration to be assigned.  This new method provides a facile solution for the determination of absolute configurations and molecular structures for many alkenes. One example is shown in Figure 2. This method should useful in the fields of chemistry and medicinal chemistry.

The Competing Enantioselective Conversion method is relatively simple to perform, and it has been developed into a laboratory experiment for the introductory organic chemistry course at UC Irvine.  Over 7000 students have performed this lab, and the vast majority of them were able to identify the correct configuration of their test alcohol.  The details of this experiment have been published.  It provides an excellent starting point to explain the concept of chirality (handedness) and teach students how the handedness of molecules affects their properties.  In this way, the laboratory experiment gives students a direct demonstration of the effect of chirality and serves to popularize science.
